The Northern Powerhouse is in danger of becoming a ‘hollow vehicle’ obsessed with ‘photo op’ schemes which could ultimately doom it to failure, it has been claimed. 
Tax expert Ben Craig says at present too much emphasis is being placed on large infrastructure projects like HS2 instead of making small changes to help attract businesses to the region. 
Mr Craig said to make the North flourish it needs 
a structure of financial incentives not only to bring firms and workers to the region, but also to retain the talent already here. Jake Berry MP, the Northern Powerhouse minister visits the new Wear Bridge at Sunderland 
He said: “As much as the North needs railways, it also needs small businesses that can flourish, grow and succeed outside of London. 
“At the moment, the main concern is the brain drain – a direct pipeline of talent and inspiration that trickles from the North to the South. 
“Graduates complete their studies in the North with an eye on a job in London. Technology start-ups form in the North but end up relocating to the capital. It’s an unhealthy situation, drawing entrepreneurs and their funding away from the region.” 
He suggested special economic zones (SEZ) which can be focused on a different emerging sector, for example Artificial intelligence, machine learning or virtual reality, creating hotspots of innovation. 
Mr Craig, manager of research and development for tax incentives for the company Ayming, said there should be tax incentives both for companies and staff to relocate to these zones. The Birmingham and Fazeley viaduct, part of the proposed route for the HS2 high speed rail scheme (Image: HS2/PA Wire) 
For companies it could be lower corporation taxes or taxation holidays where they could receive preferential rates for activities in particular regions or industries. 
For staff it could mean income tax breaks or a reduction in student loan payments. 
Mr Craig said: “These types of initiatives are effective and can gift a region its own gravitational pull, attracting forward-thinking companies. 
“Not only this, but it also acts as a carrot to foreign investment.” Read More Northern Powerhouse minister warns 'devolution is not the only game in town' during North East visit 
Mr Craig said that as well as taxation, the Government needs to review its research and development policy. 
This area, he says, is crucial to emerging technologies and so special economic zones should offer extended research & development tax credits. 
“These would provide tax reductions or cash payments against costs incurred whilst developing or improving products within a certain industry – beyond the credits already available to UK Small and Medium Sized Enterprises,” he said. 
While the North East’s exact place in the Northern Powerhouse scheme is still uncertain, the Minister responsible for it, Jake Berry, recently said ‘devolution wasn’t the only game in town’. 
With Brexit negotiations under way, Mr Craig said leaving Europe could provide fresh opportunities for the government helping UK regions develop. 
Once out of Europe, what State aid can be given out won’t be controlled as it is now by EU regulations. 
If done correctly, Mr Craig said, the Northern Powerhouse could be a prototype for Britain’s future. Read More North East left out of Northern Powerhouse meeting as it has no elected mayor 
He said: “Infrastructure is vital, as are strong, reliable and quick transport links. 
“The missing piece – the culture and environment of innovation and entrepreneurship – is needed to attract the Googles and Facebooks of this world... or help nurture their rivals.” 
He added: “I wouldn’t say it is entirely failing, I think there’s a lot of good things being done, but at the moment it’s only looking at parts of the picture.” Like us on Facebook
